Graphical abstract In the present study, for the first time the synthesis of organic–inorganic MCM-41 mesoporous magnetite nanoparticles (MNPs@MCM-41) as a new class of solid acid catalyst with large density of sulfonic acid groups was suggested. The specific surface area and textural property of synthesized nanoparticles were improved through the coupling of inorganic and organic components by template synthesis on the magnetite nanoparticle surface. The new solid acid catalyst was prepared in three steps: (i) preparation of colloidal iron oxide magnetite nanoparticles (Fe3O4 MNPs) with particle size lower than 8.0nm, (ii) development of an organic–inorganic MCM-41 mesoporous structure with thiol groups on the surface of MNPs (Fe3O4@MCM-41SH) and (iii) oxidation of thiol groups to sulfonic acid (Fe3O4@MCM-41SO3H). The incorporation of sulfonic acid as a functional group on the surface of MNPs@MCM-41 was achieved by simultaneous reaction of condensable inorganic silica species and thionilayted organic compounds (co-condensation, one-pot synthesis) that lead to magnetite mesoporous solid acid catalyst. The properties of prepared magnetite nanocomposite were characterized by FT-IR, XRD, UV-DRS, TEM, VSM and titration. Finally, the applicability of the synthesized nanocomposites was tested as heterogeneous solid acid catalyst for one-pot three component synthesis of aryl benzo[α]xanthenone derivatives in room temperature and solvent free conditions. Keywords Organic/inorganic nanocomposite Magnetite solid acid catalyst MCM-41 Xanthene 1 Introduction The development of mesoporous materials based on magnetite nanoparticles (MNPs) with large specific surface areas and good textural property is currently an area of extensive research, particularly for applications in catalysis and adsorption process [1]. In catalysis process, these materials can be superseded of homogeneous catalyst, which considered to following the green chemistry principles. The combination of the properties of MNPs and mesoporous materials within a single material is particularly attractive from the viewpoint of catalysis technique because of the possibility to combine the enormous functional groups with the advantages of magnetically property of MNPs and thermally stable and robust inorganic substrate [2–4]. This is particularly applicable to heterogeneous catalysis. The synthesis of organic/inorganic mesoporous MNPs can produce materials whose properties differ considerably from their individual, isolated components. In magnetic mesoporos, respective organosilane, organic functionalities such as alkyl, thiol, amino, vinyl, allyl, organophosphine, alkoxy, or aromatic groups can be incorporated into the silica network on the MNPs surface. Different pathways are available for the synthesis of organic/inorganic mesoporous magnetite nanocomposite [5–8]. An accepted method for synthesize organically functionalized magnetite mesoporous silica is the co-condensation method (one-pot synthesis). This method consist of preparation mesoporous magnetite nanocomposite by the co-condensation of Fe3O4 nanoparticles and tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS) with terminal tri alkoxy organosilanes of the type (R1O)3SiR2 in the presence of template agents that lead to development of a structure with organic residues anchored covalently on the Fe3O4 nanoparticles surface. Since the organic functional group is the direct component of the silica matrix layer on the MNPs, decrease in the magnetic property is not a problem in the co-condensation methods. Furthermore, the organic units are generally more homogeneously distributed in comparison with materials synthesized with the grafting process. However, the co-condensation method for synthesis of organic/inorganic mesoporous MNPs has advantages including production of reusable stable magnetite nanocomposite with high density of functional groups [9]. The mesoporous materials obtained by direct synthesis method that exhibit interesting catalytic properties. Thereby, synthesis of MNPs modified with organic/inorganic mesoporous leads to enhancement in surface area and textural properties of MNPs, which allows their usage as a very stable heterogeneous catalyst for different reactions. Sulfuric acid is one of the most important catalysts for the production of industrial chemicals. Silica supported sulfonic acid (SiO2 SO3H) has received considerable attention as an inexpensive, nontoxic and recyclable catalyst for numerous organic transformations [10,11]. Applications of silica mesoporous and silica-coated MNPs as support for sulfonic acid were reported in previous works [12,10,11,13], but this study focused on the possibility of one-pot synthesis of sulfonic acid functionalized mesoporous MNPs as a novel, active and recyclable, sulfonic acid derivative for the first time. Also, the present study shows unique advantages, such as high magnetic property, high density of sulfonic acid functional groups of the nanocomposite surface, simple synthesis of the catalyst in solvent-free conditions, easy separation of catalyst with a permanent magnet and the application of inexpensive and available precursors. Xanthene's derivatives are parent compounds of a large number of naturally occurring and synthetic derivatives, and occupy a prominent position in medicinal chemistry [14]. The synthesis of xanthenes has attracted the attention of organic chemists due to their wide ranging biological and therapeutic properties including antibacterial [15] and antiviral [16], also they are good candidates for use in photodynamic therapy [17,18]. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and apparatus All chemicals including FeCl3·6H2O, FeCl2·4H2O, tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS), cetyl trimethylamonium bromide (CTAB), 3-mercaptopropyl trimethoxy silane (MPTMS), NaOH, NaF, benzaldehyde derivatives, 1,3-cyclohexadione and β-naphthol were purchased with high purity from Fluka and Merck (Darmstadt, Germany). The crystal phases and crystallinity of synthesized MNPs were analyzed by a X-PERTPRO X-ray diffraction (PANalitical) and measured with Cu Kα radiations in the range of 1.5–80° (2θ). The quality and composition of synthesized nanoparticles were characterized by a Shimadzo Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectrometer (Japan, 470) in the range of 400–4000cm−1. The size and morphology of particles were studied by a Philips transmission electron microscopy (TEM, CM10 HT 100kV). The UV–vis absorption behavior of synthesized MNPs was characterized using a Sinco diffuse reflectance spectrophotometer (DRS, Korean, S-4100). 2.2 Preparation of Fe3O4 MNPs Fe3O4 MNPs were chemically synthesized with a little modification in the methodology already described in the literature [19]. For synthesis of Fe3O4 MNPs, 6.3g FeCl3·6H2O, 4.0g FeCl2·4H2O and 1.7mL HCl (12molL−1) were dissolved in 50mL of deionized water in a beaker in order to prepare the stock solution of ferrous and ferric chloride. After that, the solution was degassed with argon gas and heated to 80°C in a reactor. Simultaneously, the prepared solution was slowly added to the 250mL of a 1.5molL−1 ammonia solution to 80°C under argon gas protection and vigorous stirring (1000rpm). During the process, the solution temperature was kept constant at 80°C and argon gas was purged to prevent the intrusion of oxygen. After completion of the reaction, the obtained precipitate of Fe3O4 MNPs was separated from the reaction medium by the magnetic field, and then was washed four times with 500mL doubly distilled water. Finally, the obtained Fe3O4 MNPs were resuspended in 500mL of degassed deionized water. The concentration of obtained Fe3O4 MNPs were obtained as 6.2mgmL−1. 2.3 Preparation of organic/inorganic Fe3O4@MCM-41SH magnetite nanocomposite In this study, for synthesis of Fe3O4@MCM-41SH, 1.5g of synthesized MNPs and ammonia solution (5mL, 25%) were mixed with 50mL distilled water in a glass reactor and sonicated for 2min at 40°C. After mixing, tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS) (7.0mL), 3-mercapto propyl trimethoxy silane (MPTMS) (5.0mL), NaOH (0.9g) and NaF (0.19) were added to mixture and stirred for 2.0h. Then, cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB) (7.0g) was added to the mixture. The mixture was stirred at 40°C for 2.0h again. At the end of this process, the magnetic composite was hydrothermally treated at 120°C for 48h in an autoclave. After two days, the resultant solid was filtered, washed with distilled water and dried at 60°C. Finally, the template was removed by solvent extraction. For this purpose, the magnetic nanocomposites were dispersed in the mixture of ethanol/n-hexane at a 1:1 ratio and kept at 80°C for 24h. This procedure was repeated twice. 2.4 Preparation of Fe3O4@MCM-41SO3H solid acid catalyst In 20mL mixture of water/methanol (1:1), the recovered magnetic mesoporousSH nanocomposites were oxidized by 10mL of 30% hydrogen peroxide overnight at room temperature. The product was recovered magnetically and washed three times with 20mL water. The sulfonic acid-modified magnetic mesoporous nanocomposites were washed three times with distillated water and dried under vacuum at room temperature overnight. A brown solid of magnetic mesoporousSO3H (Fe3O4@MCM-41SO3H) was obtained. 2.5 General procedure for the synthesis of 9,10-dihydro-12-phenyl-8H-benzo[α]xanthen-11(12H)-one A mixture of benzaldehyde (1mmol), β-naphthol (1mmol), 1,3-cyclohexadione (1.2mmol), and synthesized sulfonic acid solid acid catalyst (0.05g) was stirred at room temperature and solvent-free conditions for 25min. The reaction products were monitored by TLC. After completion of the reaction, the mixture was triturated with ethanol. Afterward, in the presence of a magnetic stirrer bar, Fe3O4@MCM-41SO3H nanocomposites were separated and the reaction mixture turned clear. Finally, the crude product was recrystallized by EtOH to give a pure product. 3 Results and discussion In the present study, a method for synthesize of hybrid organic/inorganic MNPs with silica network by one-pot co-condensation synthetic method was suggested. In this synthesis process, the co-condensation of colloidal iron oxide MNPs, TEOS with terminal trialkoxy organosilanes (with thiol group) of the type (RO)3Si(CH2)2SH in the presence of structure-directing agent (CTAB) lead to form Fe3O4@MCM-41 with organic residues anchored covalently to the silica network on the surface of MNPs. This strategy involves Fe3O4 nanoparticles as the magnetic core coated by thiol functionalized silica mesoporous (MCM-41) as a thin layer and oxidation of thiol group to sulfonic acid (Fig. 1 ). 3.1 Characterization of synthesized solid acid catalyst Magnetite nanoparticles (Fe3O4) of 8.0nm average diameter were prepared by the chemical coprecipitation technique. The new magnetic hybrid organic/inorganic sulfonic acid catalyst was prepared in two steps: (i) development of a thiol functionalized MCM-41 mesoporous hybrid on the MNPs surface (Fe3O4@MCM-41SH) and (ii) oxidation of thiol groups to sulfonic acid (Fe3O4@MCM-41SO3H). The new synthesized nanoparticles and solid acid catalysts were evaluated via FT-IR, XRD, DRS, TEM, and VSM techniques. Also, the sulfonic acid content of magnetite nanocomposite was determined with titration. Fig. 2 shows the FT-IR spectra of the synthesized Fe3O4@MCM-41SH (before and after removal of template) and Fe3O4@MCM-41SO3H MNPs, respectively. Without removal of template, the FT-IR spectra showed high intensity peaks for the CH2 stretching modes located at ∼2850cm−1 and 2920cm−1 (symmetric and asymmetric), as well as for the CH2 bending mode at ∼1473cm−1. These modes are related to the surfactant tail and their intensities represents to the surfactant concentration. The absence of CH2 peaks in Fig. 2b confirms the surfactant removal after calcination. An intense peak at 1000–1250cm−1 corresponded to the SiO stretching vibration in the amorphous silica shell. The CH stretching and bending vibrations of tri alkoxy organosilanes are visible in the spectra at 2800–3000cm−1 and 1400cm−1 (Fig. 2a and b). Fe3O4 usually presents bands at ∼570 and 430cm−1, due to FeO vibrations in tetrahedral and octahedral sites, respectively. An intense peak at 2480cm−1 related to the SH stretching vibration in the amorphous silica shell. The absence of SH peak in 2480cm−1 in Fig. 2c confirms the oxidation process of SH to SO3H. In the case of Fe3O4@MCM-41SO3H (Fig. 2c), the sulfonic acid bonds can be observed at ∼1200–1250, 1010–1100 and 650cm−1, which are attributed to the OSO asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibrations and SO stretching vibration of the sulfonic groups (SO3H), respectively. However, in the FT-IR spectra of synthesized sulfonated nanoparticles, such bands could not be observed because they are probably overlapped by the bands of SiO2. The increase in the intensities of the bands at 3000–3500cm−1 suggests that there are more OH groups on the mesoporous MNPs surface after the sulfonation. On the other hand, the band at ∼3360cm−1 became much broader. All these observations confirm that the surface of the MNPs have been functionalized by sulfonic groups. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the mesoporous MNPs showed peaks that could be indexed both mesoporous structure and MNPs (Fig. 3 ). The MNPs indicated peaks with 2θ at 29.72°, 35.57°, 43.17°, 57.15° and 62.77° which is quite identical to pure magnetite and matched well with the XRD pattern of the standard Fe3O4 from Joint Committee on Powder Diffraction Standards (JCPDS No. 19-692) [20]. The XRD measurements of Fe3O4@MCM-41was carried out in order to obtain information about changes in the structures of crystallites MNPs. The smoothly varying peak intensity with 2θ at 10–30° range results from the amorphous silica template. The sharp three peaks with 2θ at 1.5–10° which are characteristic peaks of MCM-41. The same peaks with Fe3O4 nanoparticles, which indicates the presence of magnetite in the cave of synthesized nanocomposite. The same peaks were observed in both bare and mesoporous coated MNPs, which indicated the accuracy synthesis of the Fe3O4@MCM-41 MNPs. The magnetic hysteresis curves of MNPs are shown in Fig. 4 . The magnetizations were expressed in units of emu per gram of nanoparticles. Bare MNPs and MCM-41 mesoporous MNPs exhibited typical superparamagnetic behavior, as evidenced by a zero remanence and coercively on the magnetization loop. The large saturation magnetization of bare Fe3O4 MNPs and MCM-41 mesoporous MNPs were 79emug−1 and 60emug−1, respectively. Since, the Fe3O4 MNPs were coated with non-magnetic mesoporous hybrid a decrease in saturation magnetization can be observed after coating. Fig. 5 shows the diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (UV-DRS) of the synthesized Fe3O4 MNPs, Fe3O4@MCM-41SH, and Fe3O4@MCM-41SO3H MNPs, respectively. For the bare MNPs peak at 220nm indicated the purity of the synthesized Fe3O4. The same peaks were observed in all particles. The UV-DRS patterns thus indicate existence of the magnetic core during the all synthesized magnetite nanocomposites. Fig. 6 displays TEM images of synthesized bare Fe3O4 and Fe3O4@MCM-41SO3H. The TEM images revealed that all samples were spherical-like particles. Based on the TEM images, analysis of Fe3O4 and Fe3O4@MCM-41SO3H surface morphology demonstrated the agglomeration of many ultrafine particles with a diameter of about 8.0 and 10nm, respectively. It is most important that synthesized solid acid should possess sufficient acidic property for catalytic applications. Thereby, neutralization titration was used to determine amounts of sulfonic acid groups on the mesoporous MNPs. The amount of sulfonic acid groups determined with a little modification in the methodology already described in the literature [13]. For this purpose, the surface acidic protons of Fe3O4@MCM-41SO3H (50mg) were ion-exchanged with a saturated solution of NaCl (10mL) by sonicating. This process was repeated twice more, yielding 30mL of proton-exchanged brine solution. Therefore, to determine the loading of acid sites on the synthesized catalyst the obtained solution titrated by NaOH (0.1M) solution in presence of phenol red indicator solution. The amounts of acidic protons were found to be in the range of 2.8–2.9mmolg−1. This finding means the effective density of the acid sites. These results confirm the synthesis of MCM-41 mesoporous MNPs with a high density of acid sites (SO3H groups) functioning as a strong solid acid. 3.2 Method development The prepared magnetite nanocomposite has been tested as solid acid catalyst for synthesis of aryl benzo[α]xanthenone derivatives. An attractive feature of this method is the use of Fe3O4@MCM-41SO3H as the solid acid catalyst for synthesis of xanthene derivatives with high yield, short reaction time, room temperature and solvent free conditions. The synthesis of xanthenes, especially xanthenones, has emerged as a powerful tool in organic synthesis due to their broad applications in different fields [15,21,22,18,23,24]. Herein we demonstrate Fe3O4@MCM-41SO3H as an inexpensive, highly efficient, heterogeneous, and reusable solid acid catalyst for the preparation of 12-aryl-benzo[α]-xanthenone derivatives by the one-pot three component reaction of various aryl aldehydes, β-naphthol and 1,3-cyclohexadione under room temperature and solvent-free conditions (Fig. 7 ). The present method not only affords the products in excellent yields but also avoids the problems associated with catalyst cost, handing, safety and pollution. The amount of the catalyst is a main factor affecting the synthesis procedure. The results of varying amount of synthesized catalyst (Table 1 ), showed that the product 4 could be obtained in yield ranging from 70 to 90%. Hence, 0.05g of the Fe3O4@MCM-41SO3H can be used to catalyze the synthesis of xanthenone derivatives. In summary, the optimal conditions for the Fe3O4@MCM-41SO3H catalyzed one-pot three component reaction in synthesis of 12-aryl-benzo[α]-xanthenone involved combination of Fe3O4@MCM-41SO3H (0.05g), naphthalen-2-ol 1 (1mmol), 1,3-cyclohexadione 2 (1.2mmol), and benzaldeyde 3 (1mmol) at room temperature under solvent-free conditions. In view of the obtained results, the optimized conditions were selected to determine the scope of this Fe3O4@MCM-41SO3H catalyzed reaction. A wide range of aromatic aldehydes were subjected to react with naphthalen-2-ol and 1,3-cyclohexadione in the presence of 0.05g Fe3O4@MCM-41SO3H to generate products, the results are summarized in Table 2 . Importantly, note that the super paramagnetic property of synthesized nano-catalyst made the isolation and reuse of this catalyst very easy. A plausible mechanism of catalyst working in the reaction was shown in Fig. 8 . After completion of the reaction and separation of catalyst from reaction mixture the catalyst washed with ethanol and dried in air, the Fe3O4@MCM-41SO3H was directly reused without any deactivation even after five rounds of synthesis of product 4 (Table 3 ). Various methods have been reported for the synthesis of benzoxanthenones, including, condensation of aromatic aldehydes, β-naphthols and dicarbonyl compounds in presence of different catalysts. A comparison between the result of the proposed catalyst and some of the recently used catalysts for synthesis of xanthenone derivatives is summarized in Table 4 . Although, some of these methods have convenient protocols with good to high yields, the majority of these methods suffer at least from one of the following disadvantages such as low yields, the need for a prolonged reaction time, the use of toxic organic solvents, excess reagents, and harsh reaction conditions. Table 4 shows that the heterogeneous catalyst of Fe3O4@MCM-41SO3H is the best in comparison to other mentioned catalysts. The proposed new catalyst has some advantages in comparison with the other catalyst including shorter reaction time, activity as stereoselective catalyst, easy separation via external magnetic field, low consumption of organic solvents and ability to perform reactions in solvent free conditions. It is a stable solid acid catalyst with high densities of sulfuric acid groups that can be easily synthesized in the lab and can be reused for several times. 4 Conclusion In conclusion, Fe3O4@MCM-41SO3H has been shown to be a stable and highly active catalyst for preparing a variety of 12-aryl-benzo[α]xanthenone derivatives from the one-pot three-component condensation reaction. The catalytic research on novel approaches toward magnetic mesoporous nanoparticles should be improved to enhance organic synthesis. For that purpose, magnetic mesoporous catalyst provides high surface area for interaction of compounds. This catalyst can provide new way for continuous processes, because of its simple recyclability. Good yields, short reaction times, solvent-free conditions, room temperature and a recyclable catalyst with a very easy operation are the most important advantages of synthesized catalyst.
